<panel  header="**5. :fas-info-circle: Resolving JavaFX Cross-Platform Issues with Gradle JavaFX Plugin**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/173" expanded>

## Preface

There has been several issues open about not being able to run the JAR cross-platform for various reasons, most occurring because the Gradle setup for JavaFX was using the following:

```groovy
plugins ``{``
    // ...
    id 'checkstyle'
    id 'org.openjfx.javafxplugin' version '0.0.13'
``}``

javafx ``{``
    version = '17.0.7'
    modules = ['javafx.base', 'javafx.controls', 'javafx.fxml', 'javafx.graphics']
``}``
```

The error is a `QuantumReader` error.

## Solution

I was digging through the official OpenJFX documentation to find a potential fix that continued using the (formerly) second method of importing JavaFX in Gradle:

![Screenshot 2023-09-22 at 09 48 38](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/assets/29497029/52c6a140-9774-4cb6-adbf-34c001bd7f6e)

This is my `build.gradle` now. I've tested out the JAR on a Windows ARM build emulated on Mac M1 Pro machine:

```gradle
plugins ``{``
    // ...
    id 'checkstyle'
    id 'org.openjfx.javafxplugin' version '0.0.13'
``}``

dependencies ``{``
    testImplementation group: 'org.junit.jupiter', name: 'junit-jupiter-api', version: '5.10.0'
    testRuntimeOnly group: 'org.junit.jupiter', name: 'junit-jupiter-engine', version: '5.10.0'
    implementation group: 'com.google.code.gson', name: 'gson', version: '2.10.1'

    // Used for loops to clean up the imports
    def platforms = ["win", "linux", "mac"]
    def javafxDependency = ["javafx-graphics", "javafx-controls", "javafx-fxml"]

    for (plt in platforms) ``{``
        for (dep in javafxDependency) ``{``
            runtimeOnly "org.openjfx:$dep:$javafx.version:$plt"
        ``}``
    ``}``
``}``


// ...

javafx ``{``
    version = '17.0.7'
    modules = ['javafx.base', 'javafx.controls', 'javafx.fxml', 'javafx.graphics']
``}``
```

I am currently setting up VMs (both emulated and virtualized) on a Macbook Pro 14 (M1 Pro) to test various platforms. Would be great if others could try this fix too and see if it resolves their cross-platform issue.

|OS|Architecture|Works?|
|--|------------|------|
|MacOS|ARM (M1 Pro)| âœ… |
|Windows|ARM (Virtualized)| âœ… |
|Windows|x86 (Live Machine)| âœ… |
|Linux|x86 (Ubuntu Live Machine)| âœ… |

Note: I still have the Gradle checkstyle plugin so there is no need to delete it when using this method
</panel>

<panel  header="**6. :fas-info-circle: Auto-expanding all collapsed windowsðŸ’¡**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/103" expanded>

I've noticed that even in the textbook, there are sections in Week 4's slides that are collapsed. So I wrote a quick script in JS to auto-expand all of these sections so it's much easier to search for content:

```js
const collapsibles = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.card-header'))
const uncollapsed = collapsibles.filter(node => ``{``
    const glyph = node.querySelector('.glyphicon')
    if (!glyph) return false;
    return glyph.classList.contains('glyphicon-chevron-right')
``}``)
uncollapsed.forEach(node => node.click())
```

To run it, just open the developer console in the page in question and paste in the script into the console and run it

(Noticed that previous semesters have had similar scripts too)

Hope this helps someone! :) 
</panel>

<panel  header="**11 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/18#issuecomment-1690964713" expanded>

It's likely something to do with redirection relying on a single `System.in`: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27286690/in-java-is-it-possible-to-re-open-system-in-after-closing-it

When reading input from the redirected file, the first Scanner closes `System.in` and so resulting uses of `System.in` will fail. This doesn't occur in manual input since `System.in` is available for each new line you enter
</panel>

<panel  header="**15 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/22#issuecomment-1691857737" expanded>

You need `git push --tags` otherwise your tag will not be published

`git tag` alone will only add a tag locally, your remote repository does not contain the tag
</panel>

<panel  header="**16 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/22#issuecomment-1691864201" expanded>

I would also add that it's best if you don't try to think of commands as a sequence to memorise but rather as a set of tasks that need to be done, this way it's easier to handle issues like merge conflicts or multiple branches:

1. `git add &lt;file>`: stage the file for the next "snapshot"/commit
2. `git commit -m`: create the "snapshot"/commit with a message
3. `git tag`: provide the current "snapshot"/commit with a human readable tag name
4. `git push`: bring changes from local repository to remote repository, does not include tags
5. `git push --tags`: bring all local tags to remote repository

This way, it's much easier when dealing with larger commits/projects, hope this helps 
</panel>

> a solution to set the default encoding when compiling/running the java program using gradle will be required

I'm not entirely sure if this is even possible to dictate for your users through Gradle ðŸ¤” . Once the program is running, your user's terminal encoding is the one that dictates what characters show up.

One really hack-y way is to forcefully set your user's terminal encoding by directly running commands when your bot starts such as using `Runtime.exec()` (https://www.baeldung.com/run-shell-command-in-java). You could try playing around with the `LC_ALL` of the user's configuration to see if that ensures "global" viewing but as pointed out in [this article](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36184019/is-it-possible-force-utf-8-in-a-c-program), doing this could be a very slippery slope as the user's encoding affects things outside of just displaying the symbols

For Unix systems, `LC_ALL` seems to be sufficient but for Windows, you might need to try this: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35549962/lc-all-c-equivalent-for-windows-using-powershell

<panel  header="**42 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/107#issuecomment-1707495243" expanded>

I think the main idea is to have a **logical separation** of concerns and to not create new classes for the sake of creating a class. This goes back to what the problem is. Let's say you are trying to implement a builder pattern, out of necessity, a secondary (usually nested) `Builder` class is needed. This is a logical separation of work since you need this `Builder` class for you to be able to properly implement the pattern. An instance where creating a class for the sake of creating a class is going to be redundant is in cases where you have a single utility method used in a single location but you try abstracting it out into a "utility" class just because you can. In those scenarios, I would just leave the utility method in the class it is used since it's not going to ever be used outside.

Besides the "need" concern, I think a bigger component of modularity is the ability to have finer unit testing. Larger modules/classes imply that you have a lot more surface area to cover for a unit test. This is not a bad thing per-se but being able to modularize the code means that you decouple long dependency chains so that each unit test covers exactly one component and does not have to overextend its testing. One very good example is the `Parser` class in iP where having a separate class means you can individually test `parse()` without having to worry about setting up the file storage or making sure the bot is running.

For most web frameworks (think Gin for Go, Spring Boot for Java, Phoenix for Elixir), it is not uncommon to see a high level of modularity when building out a single endpoint. Usually you have a router to handle the web routes, then you have a controller to handle the HTTP request, and then a set of models that the controller uses, and finally a data layer that connects with the database. This modularity, while verbose and tedious at times, gives a very clear flow of what goes where and the roles each class/module plays. Even in desktop applications, you might see architectures like the Model-View-Controller (MVC) where you already have three layers of modularity.

Tl;dr: dividing into multiple classes is a double edged sword, it gives clear visibility and responsibility to each file which makes testing a lot easier but overdoing it because you can is bound to make the code more unreadable and harder to navigate
</panel>

<panel  header="**44 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/125#issuecomment-1712436412" expanded>

I've forked your repository and managed to rectify the issue. The primary issue is the use of `Pane` to wrap your dialog messages (for some odd reason, it does not allow the wrap text to work as expected). You can use `HBox` to arrange the content already. You also need to configure the parent container (`VBox` in `ScrollPane`) to have a fixed width too. I've updated the view through FXML directly so I removed the `children` nodes but the general logic applies. You might want to re-adjust some of the values I hardcoded to suit your needs but believe it's best to show what changes were needed:

`MainWindow.fxml`:

```xml

            prefWidth="400.0" xmlns="http://javafx.com/javafx/17" xmlns:fx="http://javafx.com/fxml/1"
            fx:controller="cheems.gui.MainWindow">

               AnchorPane.bottomAnchor="1.0"/>

            prefHeight="41.0" prefWidth="76.0" text="Send"/>
&gt;!-- here -->
    <ScrollPane fx:id="scrollPane" hbarPolicy="NEVER" prefHeight="557.0" prefWidth="400.0"
                styleClass="chat" stylesheets="@../css/Application.css" vvalue="1.00" hvalue="1.0">
        <VBox fx:id="dialogContainer" prefWidth="388.0"/>
    </ScrollPane>
</AnchorPane>
```

`DialogBox.fxml`:

```xml
<fx:root alignment="TOP_RIGHT" maxHeight="Infinity" maxWidth="1.7976931348623157E308" prefWidth="400.0"
         type="javafx.scene.layout.HBox" xmlns="http://javafx.com/javafx/17.0.2-ea" xmlns:fx="http://javafx.com/fxml/1">
    <padding>
        <Insets bottom="15.0" left="10.0" right="10.0" top="15.0"/>
    </padding>
    <Circle fx:id="circle" fill="#007df2" radius="23.0" stroke="BLACK" strokeType="INSIDE" strokeWidth="0.0">
        <HBox.margin>
            <Insets left="10.0" right="10.0"/>

        <font>
            <Font name="Segoe UI" size="14.0"/>
        </font>
        <padding>
            <Insets bottom="15" top="15" left="20" right="20" />
        </padding>

1. Remove the use of Pane since `HBox` already handles alignment of content
2. Remove the `prefHeight` attribute of the `VBox` inside `ScrollPane` since that would cause scrolling issues with longer texts from my experience

<panel  header="**50 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/134#issuecomment-1713463019" expanded>

I personally do not see an alternative to testing it as is. I view unit testing practices as guidelines that should be done when possible. In this scenario, if you are worried about the reliability of returning the instance `Bar`, then the thing you should focus on is not the fact that there is a dependency, but rather, making sure that `Bar` is properly unit tested separately. This way, you are "guaranteed" that `fooMethod` would not be buggy.

The key here is to make sure `Bar` is independently tested (or as much as it can be) and that way, you are sure there is no issues returning a new instance of it from `Foo`. You shouldn't need to test the `Bar` object returned from `fooMethod` inside `Foo` since then you would have overlapping unit tests. So there's two separate test files, `BarTest` and `FooTest` and you don't mix the unit tests

That's my take on this
</panel>

<panel  header="**54 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/147#issuecomment-1722229117" expanded>

I think this really boils down to what is defined as a magic literal. An interesting paper I found was this: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0950584922000908

And it defines magic literals as 

> Magic literals are such values used without an explicit explanation of their meaning.

So the key component to what makes magic literals magic is the fact that there is a lack of **explicit** explanation of their meaning. In the case of 'String.format()', the strings that you use are self-explanatory, they are simply the contents to print and the interpolated variables should be explained in their own ways. So I don't think that this is a magic literal and it does not affect the readability of the code.

As for whether it is alright to use magic strings, I see this as being a similar problem to writing SQL code in another language. For instance, is it better to include the SQL query directly like (using Go to illustrate but the idea applies):

'''go
db.Query('
SELECT *
FROM users
WHERE username = $1
', username)
'''

Or if it's better to abstract this query into a separate string such as:

'''go
const QUERY = '
SELECT *
FROM users
WHERE username = $1
'

db.Query(QUERY, username)
'''

I think in this case, having an extra layer of abstraction might actually make it harder to understand the intent of the code and make it harder to trace. You could imagine the 'QUERY' being stored in a separate file so you will have to jump between files to figure out these magic literals. I think the SQL string is self-explanatory, albeit slightly long but it doesn't really violate SLAP since it's still along the same level of abstraction.

This is just my take on this though, would love to hear what others think!
</panel>

<panel  header="**55 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/147#issuecomment-1722797823" expanded>

> Moving it to one location as a NAMED_CONSTANT can make future updates to it easier and less error-prone.

I agree, however, I might argue that if it's used in `String.format()`, it's unlikely to be reused so moving it to another location could be considered as a premature optimisation that might not be necessary. I think this really boils down to the context and use case of the literal.
</panel>

The beauty of Git and version control is that you get to work asynchronously and sync your work anytime in the flow (but before you push to `master`). Generally, if the upstream `master` is updated, you could merge the latest changes into your branch using:

```
git fetch upstream master
git merge upstream/master
```

Run on your local branch, before anymore dev work. But fret not if you did not do so, you can do it after you've finished your changes, or through Github's PR UI that will also prompt you to merge to `master` to remain latest before you can merge your PR :)

<panel  header="**2. :fas-info-circle: Whether or not parsing of negative index and zero be considered a duplicate bug**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/512" expanded>

Hi, our team received multiple bug reports regarding the error message provided is less helpful when users inputed negative index/zero(e.g. `delete -1` would show a command format error rather than index out of bound error). This behaviour is expected as we specified that index should be in the range of `[1, 2147483647]`, which makes 0 and negative indices not a valid input to index, hence a command format error.

We are going to accept this bug as a NotInScope feature flaw, but we are not very sure whether or not both cases (i.e. 0 and negative indices) can be considered a duplicate or must he seperate bugs.

So the fix required is to modify the parse index method to not only accept unsigned positive integers, but also negative integers and zero, one could argue that these can be fixed separately (i.e. we can fix the parsing to accept zero but not negative and vice versa), but we think that since both zero and negative integers are within the same equivalence partition, it would also be valid to say both should be fixed together. That is, we think that they seem like one enhancement rather than two, as it wouldn't make sense to accept 0 which is already out of our current allowed indices range, but still reject negative indices.

However, we are not very sure can we merge these bugs as duplicate and is seeking advice here.
</panel>

<panel  header="**5. :fas-info-circle: Question regarding bug type when a feature can be used but not documented**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/476" expanded>

I came across this scenario when considering possible bugs in PE, that there is a feature that can be used but not documented and I am thinking what kind of bug is this. Consider the following cases:

**Case 1:** 
The team actually wanted the feature, but forgot to document about it. I would deem this to be a documentation bug.

**Case 2:**
The team did not want the feature to be included in their application, but they could possibly forgot to remove it and was inherited from AB3. Then this would be a functionality bug right? As the application is not functioning as it is supposed to be.

Then for both cases, would the severity of the bug be determined by what kind of consequences could arise from using that feature? For instance, clearing the whole data (the clear command from the AB3) could be quite a severe case as it is a destructive and non-recoverable operation, so maybe severity.Medium/severity.High?

On top of that, as it is fully up to the developer team to decide on whether they wanted to include such features, are there any guidelines on how we should determine which case it is? If it were to be case1, we might need to consider whether the feature has any flaws or not, but for case2, since the feature was not supposed to be there at the first place, any flaws in the feature should not be reported too.
</panel>

<panel  header="**7. :fas-info-circle: Questions regarding severity categorisation for UML diagrams error**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/393" expanded>

I am wondering what kind of severity should we categorise errors in UML diagrams to? Does it depend on how the error affects the readability/understandability?

A simple example would be, in a sequence diagram where we want to indicate loops:

**Scenario 1:**
We used the label `for` instead of `loop` in the top left corner.
I would categorise this as a severity.veryLow since it does not actually cause misunderstanding, rather just a wrong notation.

**Scenario 2:**
We used the label `opt` instead of `loop` in the top left corner.
This would then upgrade to a severity.Low or severity.Medium since it will cause misunderstanding?

If the above example is correct, would that mean syntax/notation errors that do not cause misunderstanding can be categorised as severity.veryLow bugs, whereas bugs that actually cause misunderstanding will categorised from severity.Low upwards depending on how much it affects? But then there would be a grey area of when the diagram is too cluttered which affects readability(even though the diagram is totally correct), which I am not very sure how we should categorise, since it is technically a cosmetic issue, but it will also heavily affect readers to understand the diagram.

All in all, I understand that a lot of these need to be determined on a case by case basis, but I am just wondering whether are there any general guidelines on categorising severity of UML diagram errors?

</panel>

If you are still facing issues, you can use these following commands. 

1. Open up your terminal and navigate to your iP folder
2. Type command `git log` to list all the recent commits

For example, mine looks like this:
![image](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/assets/96157054/c80d85d6-a39a-47cb-a104-7a180a7fba6e)

&hat;My tag above is listed with the merge commit, so I know the merge commit has been tagged correctly. 

From your screenshot, it seems to me that your tag is not attached to the merge commit, which might be what is causing the issue.

1. Run `git log` and make sure all your commits are synced with your local repositiory
2. Delete the old tag from your local repository using `git tag -d &lt;tag-name>`
3. Create the tag on the new commit using `git tag &lt;tag-name> &lt;hash-of-the-merge-commit>`
4. Delete the old tag from the remote repositiory `git push origin --delete &lt;tag-name>`
5. Push the new tag to the remote repository `git push origin &lt;tag-name>`

This method has worked for me before, and it should for you as well ðŸ˜Š

Actually I think i noticed the culprit. In the image that you attached at the start of the thread, I noticed that you have a `ParserTest` class that is not in a subdirectory of its own.

<panel  header="**31 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/249#issuecomment-1759469324" expanded>

You can test for the error being thrown. (Similar to what Prof Damith has said)

Example:
```java
import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.assertThrows;

import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;

public class CalendarTest ``{``

    @Test
    public void testDeleteAtInvalidIndex() ``{``
        Calendar calendar = new Calendar();
        // Add some events to the calendar

        assertThrows(AssertionError.class, () -&gt; ``{``
            calendar.deleteAt(-1); // or any invalid index
        ``}``);
    ``}``
``}``
```

Specifically, you may find AssertionError.class to be useful here.

</panel>

To set the context, I am looking to implement a calendar feature for the tP. Following the project structure of AB3, I added a class called `Calendar` to model a calendar, which would store `Event` objects.

Now, I am wondering what would be the better practice to write my `Calendar` class `deleteAt(int index)` method, knowing that the index will definitely be valid?

(A) No assumption about `index` validity

    if (index < 0 || index > this.size - 1) ``{``

    ``}``

    eventList.delete(index);

<panel  header="**20 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/22#issuecomment-1691868266" expanded>

> I would also add that it's best if you don't try to think of commands as a sequence to memorise but rather as a set of tasks that need to be done, this way it's easier to handle issues like merge conflicts or multiple branches:
> 
> 1. `git add &lt;file>`: stage the file for the next "snapshot"/commit
> 2. `git commit -m`: create the "snapshot"/commit with a message
> 3. `git tag`: provide the current "snapshot"/commit with a human readable tag name
> 4. `git push`: bring changes from local repository to remote repository
> 5. `git push --tags`: bring all local tags to remote repository
> 
> This way, it's much easier when dealing with larger commits/projects, hope this helps

<panel  header="**25 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/310#issuecomment-1784573963" expanded>

> @lihongguang00 It might help to share the relevant code, or point to a relevant PR.

Hi prof,

Unfortunately, I do not have any PR or code to point to because I have chosen to take another route around it. 

But to give more context for the purposes of discussion, our project involves a calendar system (similar to NUSMods), and we have a `StackPane` (container) that holds the 1. background of the calendar and 2. the event cards for the calendar. However, because our team wanted to make the calendar only display the necessary time periods to minimise clutter (similar to how NUSMods will change the time periods displayed according to the earliest class and latest class of the day), this requires the width of the background to be updated (as more hours displayed will require more pixels). As a result, the container is not synchronized with the background, resulting in spaces in the container that are not filled by the background.   &lt;module name="SuppressWithPlainTextCommentFilter">
    &lt;property name="offCommentFormat" value="// CHECKSTYLE\.OFF\: ([\w\|]+)"/>
    &lt;property name="onCommentFormat" value="// CHECKSTYLE\.ON\: ([\w\|]+)"/>
    &lt;property name="checkFormat" value="$1"/>
  &lt;/module>
  
  from https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/7287

<panel  header="**22 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/235#issuecomment-1744060786" expanded>

Problem solved:
Adding this line to build.gradle dependencies did it
```
testImplementation 'org.junit.platform:junit-platform-launcher:1.4.0'
```

I placed it in this section

```
    testImplementation group: 'org.junit.jupiter', name: 'junit-jupiter-api', version: jUnitVersion
    testRuntimeOnly group: 'org.junit.jupiter', name: 'junit-jupiter-engine', version: jUnitVersion
    testImplementation 'org.junit.platform:junit-platform-launcher:1.4.0'
```
</panel>

<panel  header="**17 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/414#issuecomment-1807054587" expanded>

I think the main issue is with how git handles revert.

In Git, when a branch (lets say branch A) is merged into the main repository and then its merge commit is subsequently reverted, any new PR from branch A is seen as having no new changes, and not allowed at all. This is because Git tracks the state of the code rather than individual PRs or branches. 

In your case, branch 2, which reverts all the changes made in branch 1, is merged. Thus, Git recognizes that the changes from branch 1 are effectively nullified. And so, the PR for branch 1 is automatically closed by GitHub because, from Git's perspective, its changes are already accounted for in the main branch through the merge and revert process of branch 2. 

To avoid this, you can use git reset instead of git revert, as it alters the commit history differently. [Here](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/git-difference-between-git-revert-checkout-and-reset/) is more info on the behaviours of reset and revert. 
</panel>

text-ui-test/EXPECTED-UNIX.TXT
```

So only `text-ui-test/ACTUAL.TXT` and `text-ui-test/EXPECTED-UNIX.TXT` are untracked by Git.

In order words, your testing input file `text-ui-test/input.txt` and the expected output file `text-ui-test/EXPECTED.TXT` will still be tracked and can be committed ðŸ˜„
</panel>

<panel  header="**4. :fas-info-circle: Questions on planned enhancement**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/507" expanded>

1. Our team received bug of [one planned enhancement containing multiple distinct enhancements](https://catcher-org.github.io/CATcher/phaseTeamResponse/issues/339). It quotes the requirement on website:

`FAQ: Enhancement X and Y are very similar. Can we count them as one? Answer: Only if adding one automatically adds the other. If one can be added without the other, they are counted as two enhancements.`

And stated that **changing font sizes at two different parts in UI** should be considered as 2 separate enhancements. We think it over-interpretting what's stated in FAQ, as it would lead to situation like adding or modifying a whole feature can be considered as 1 enhancement but the tiny change here is considered as 2 enhancements, which doesn't make sense.

Thus, may I clarify that as long as the enhancement is aimed to achievement the same purpose, even if it changes multiple lines of code in one Java file, **such as changing styles in CSS file, or fixing all grammar and inconsistent error messages in one file `Message.java`**,  it could be considered as 1 enhancement?

2. It is [previously answered in forum](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/475) that 

`If the team has exceeded the allowed count in the planned enhancements, only the first N items (where N is team size x 2) in that list will have immunity. The rest can be reported as bugs. In addition, exceeding the count can be reported as a separate DG bug.`

If there are still vacancies in our planned enhancement, could we reject the issue regarding issues like [one planned enhancement containing multiple distinct enhancements](https://catcher-org.github.io/CATcher/phaseTeamResponse/issues/339)? Because it should not be considered as a bug since we don't exceed the allowed count.

Thank you!
</panel>

<panel  header="**10 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/122#issuecomment-1711095245" expanded>

@JasonRay You need to add the `@FXML` labels to `dialog` and `displayPicture` - otherwise your FXML files will not be able to detect the variables.

You can see this from your error message - its leading you to line 41 with a `NullPointerException` - you are calling `setText` on an uninitialized label, so it's not automatically loading in from the FXML file.

> The 2 fields dialog and displayPicture were used, but the corresponding field declarations at the top was not highlighted purple, meaning it is not used

Regarding this, the IDE doesn't seem to detect variable usage in FXML files, even with the `@FXML` tag - don't be too alarmed by this.


</panel>

<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: Missing CS2101 context when testing documentation**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/530" expanded>

I am exempted from CS2101, and thus am taking CS2103 standalone. My tutorial mates and I have never taken the former course and do not have access to its materials. Thus I have not heard about the goings-on in that course; I have no context as to the additional requirements that it turns out CS2101 places on this course's documentation, such as the UG.

Still, I was assigned to test the product of a team whose documentation has to fulfill both courses' rubrics. I was thus missing important context under which some of that team's documentation was written and _phrased_ (e.g. tone), and the reasons behind why they may have made certain decisions that differ from that of the teams I have seen so far.

It is only now that my assigned team has responded, including content such as screenshots, files, and keywords that I am finding out/hearing about for the first time, that I am learning of this difference. This has negatively impacted my report accuracy, especially since I was only able to make mainly documentation-related reports for their product for lack of other types of issues found. Had I known some of this information beforehand, I would have made my reports differently/made different reports altogether.

Will any of this be taken into account when it comes to grading for accuracy? I feel like this would not have been a concern had the team assignment been done amongst teams who are also not taking CS2101.
</panel>

<panel  header="**2. :fas-info-circle: Is team member count factored into project grading?**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/461" expanded>

[Part 2B of the TP grading page](https://nus-cs2103-ay2324s1.github.io/website/admin/tp-grading.html#2-project-grading-implementation-15-marks) mentions that effort for the entire project gets evaluated by both testers (peers) and tutors.

On average, the percentage of total effort in comparison to AB3 that a team with less members would be able to put in would be lower than that of a team with more members, if all members are aiming to put in an IP's worth of effort. Therefore, a team with less members may get a lower effort score from testers and/or tutors, especially if the tester has a different frame of reference from being in a team with more members.

Will such a lower effort score get "re-weighted" to account for teams with less members? For reference, I am in a tutorial with only 4 people total, so we automatically formed a team of 4.
</panel>

<panel  header="**3. :fas-info-circle: How to handle 6 separate, extra DG pages that came with AB3**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/383" expanded>

AB3 came with 6 separate, extra pages linked in the DG. These are the setup/getting started, documentation, logging, testing, configuration & devops pages.

The grading details on the course website state:

> The main content you add should be in the `docs/DeveloperGuide.md` file (for ease of tracking by grading scripts).

Our changes to the product render some of these extra pages outdated. We have also already made some updates to these pages. Additionally, some of these pages are rather short as is (like the configuration page).

May I know what a good way to handle these extra pages would be? Some potential options I could think of:

- Make minimal updates to the pages such that they aren't outdated
- Or flesh out the content of the pages
- Or scrap the pages entirely
- Or merge the pages into the DG (presumably to ensure they count for grading)
- etc.

There are also the tutorials that we used to familiarise with AB3, but we have already scrapped those.
</panel>

<panel  header="**3 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/5#issuecomment-1687019311" expanded>

On macOS, JDK versions are permanently installed in /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines. You need to `cd` into that directory and `sudo rm -rf` that particular version of Java. The Application Support directory contains Java itself (the Application to support the running of Java apps on macOS), which (iirc) is different from JDK (the Java Development Kit used to compile and run Java code).

The instructions [here](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/install/mac_jdk.html) are clearer.
</panel>

<panel  header="**5 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/120#issuecomment-1710941098" expanded>

Hey, I would like to suggest trying out the [second method](https://openjfx.io/openjfx-docs/#gradle). 
I could not set up JavaFX properly with the first method too but this one worked for me! I tweaked the steps a little to make it work for my project and the import statements (finally) got recognized :)

Setup steps(some steps are slightly different since the version of JavaFX that the tutorial uses is JavaFX 17.0.7):
1. In your build.gradle file, add the following to your `build.gradle` file on top of your existing plugins:
(this adds the JavaFX plugin for Gradle)
```
plugins ``{``
    id 'org.openjfx.javafxplugin' version '0.0.13'
``}``
```
2. In your `build.gradle` file, also add the following:
(the snippet below specifies that JavaFX 17.0.7 should be used, and that we need the 'javafx.controls' & 'javafx.fxml' modules, FXML can be omitted if you do not plan to use FXML to develop your chatbot GUI)
```
javafx ``{``
    version = "17.0.7"
    modules = [ 'javafx.controls', 'javafx.fxml' ]
``}``
```
3. Run your `build.gradle` file:
- Linux/Mac: `./gradlew run`
- Windows: `gradlew run`

Really hope this helps! Jiayous!
</panel>

Adding this to my build.gradle has solved the issue below:
> Execution failed for task ':DukeLauncher.main()'.
> Process 'command '/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/zulu-11.jdk/Contents/Home/bin/java'' finished with non-zero exit value 1
Caused by: java.lang.RuntimeException: Error initializing QuantumRenderer: no suitable pipeline found

Thanks @AlagappanRa :)

As for the checkstyle breaking, it turns out that I did not delete the module-info.java file from my repo, which is required for the first method of installing but not the second. So if anyone is reverting to the first method of including JavaFX, you might want to follow the steps below for reverting to the first method:
- Remove any JavaFX SDKs that you might have installed for the second method(delete it from whereever that you might have placed the JavaFX SDK in when you first set up JavaFX)
- Remove these lines that you had to add for the second method from your `build.gradle` file:
```gradle
javafx ``{``
    version = "17.0.7"
    modules = [ 'javafx.controls', 'javafx.fxml' ]
``}``
```
- Delete any module-info.java files(not needed for including JavaFX using the first method)
- Include these lines in your dependencies file(credits: @AlagappanRa):
```gradle
dependencies ``{``
    // JavaFX 17.0.7 dependencies for macOS on ARM64
    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-base:17.0.7:mac-aarch64'
    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-controls:17.0.7:mac-aarch64'
    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-fxml:17.0.7:mac-aarch64'
    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-graphics:17.0.7:mac-aarch64' 

    // JavaFX 17.0.7 dependencies for Linux
    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-base:17.0.7:linux'
    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-controls:17.0.7:linux'
    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-fxml:17.0.7:linux'
    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-graphics:17.0.7:linux'

    // JavaFX 17.0.7 dependencies for Windows
    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-base:17.0.7:win'
    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-controls:17.0.7:win'
    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-fxml:17.0.7:win'
    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-graphics:17.0.7:win'
``}``
```
- note: what the above lines do is to include distributions for other OSes(as described in the comments), so the resulting jar file generated will be cross-platform(I have yet to try it out on other OSes but I will keep everyone posted)
- Next, run `./gradlew build` in order to set up the project dependencies to include the required JavaFX components in your project
- Verify that the dependencies have been added by going to `File -&gt; Project Structure -&gt; Project Settings -&gt; Modules -&gt; Dependencies`. You should see the below:
<img width="898" alt="Screenshot 2023-09-21 at 5 06 38 PM" src="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/assets/66860275/35435a56-9352-4aea-9f29-9bc3a0f34108">
- Ensure your ip still works by running your ip as per usual
- Ensure that your checkstyle still works after making the above changes(if applicable)
</panel>

<panel  header="**5 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/30#issuecomment-1705655827" expanded>

I appreciate the thoughtful discussion on whether to have a separate Storage class in our project. I'd like to share some strengths and advantages of having a dedicated Storage class, despite the tight coupling with TaskList that we've observed:

1. Isolation of Saving/Writing Operations:

One of the key benefits of introducing a Storage class is that it provides a clear separation of concerns. It isolates the task of saving and writing data from the rest of the application logic. This separation makes our codebase more maintainable and adheres to the Single Responsibility Principle (SRP), a fundamental principle in software design.
By encapsulating file I/O operations within the Storage class, we reduce the risk of scattering file-related code throughout the TaskList class. This isolation can help us manage and debug these operations more effectively.

2. Error Handling and Abstraction:

Another advantage of having a Storage class is the opportunity it provides for centralized error handling and abstraction. We can implement error-checking and exception handling in one place within the Storage class, ensuring that any issues related to data storage are handled consistently.
Furthermore, as pointed out by another participant. if we decide to support different data storage formats or locations in the future, the Storage class can serve as an abstraction layer. This allows us to change the underlying storage mechanisms without affecting the TaskList class or other parts of our application. It promotes flexibility and future-proofing.

3. Code Organization and Readability:

From a code organization perspective, having a Storage class can improve the overall readability of our code. It abstracts away low-level file operations and provides a more human-readable interface for saving and loading data. This can make the code within the TaskList class cleaner and easier to understand. 

4. Potential for Future Features:

While our project may not currently have additional data storage needs beyond the TaskList, designing a Storage class can set a foundation for future features. If we ever need to manage other data files alongside the task list, having a dedicated Storage class will make it easier to extend our codebase without introducing unnecessary complexity. Also helps to facilitate reading of same file to multiple task lists and vice versa, helping with versions of files and tasks list.
</panel>

@woojiahao 

Thanks for your help! I believe I have had both Java 11 and Java 17 installed previously.

My particular error: 
Files executed successfully if SDK under Project Structure is 17. Since this project requires Java 11, I tried switching SDK to 11 but when running Duke.java, error occurs. 

My steps of resolving the error:
1. File -&gt; Project Structure -&gt; SDK (choose 11) -&gt; Language Level (choose Default) -&gt; Apply -&gt; OK. (https://www.baeldung.com/intellij-change-java-version from CS2040S setup / @woojiahao )

2. IntelliJ IDEA (beside File) -&gt; Build, Execution, Deployment -&gt; Compiler -&gt; Java Compiler -&gt; Project bytecode version (set to 11) -&gt; Apply -&gt; OK. (from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/67098514/java-error-release-version-17-not-supported)

3. Build (same menu bar as File and IntelliJ IDEA) -&gt; Rebuild Project.

4. Run Duke.java. Should run successfully.

</panel>

<panel  header="**6 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/16#issuecomment-1690907997" expanded>

From website:

Q. How are the iP git tags used in grading?

A. Adding a git tag in the iP is a self-declaration that you think you are done with the iP increment. We take your word for it. We don't check the code to see if you have actually done the said increment. Therefore, it is just a mechanism for you to self-declare progress and for us to monitor those progress declarations.

So I think you can just change it at the Level-5 commit onwards 
</panel>

<panel type="info" header="### 37. JED ..KEAT `@jedkohjk` (12 posts) "  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: Clarification on bugs involving crashing the app with specific data files**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/535" expanded>

Hi,

I refer to #510. In #510 , the poster says that inserting a `null` value in the data file causes the app to **crash**.

Prof @damithc responded by saying that the app only needs to support what is specified in the AB3 User Guide, with the following screenshot:

![image](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/assets/110604064/49f325bc-6a9e-4c26-90ed-b8be5bb1e8dd)

He then goes on to say:

> Recovering from improper edits to the data file (or other config files) was not an expectations at v1.4, unless you specifically stated such a feature in the UG.

However, there is a misalignment between the AB3 User Guide and the behaviour of the poster's program (btw, I was not a tester for this poster, I am asking a more general question).

According to the AB3 User Guide, should the data file be invalid, the app will be cleared. However, in this case, the app completely crashes/does not start with an invalid data file. The app does not fail gracefully.

Hence, the 2 statements by Prof seem to contradict. I want to ask about which is correct.

I think the mismatch between user guide and app may confuse real users (again, I know the poster changed their user guide, but I'm speaking more generally).

To give an example, consider the following scenario from AB3:

The user uses tags to store projects they work on together with a given person and the original data file is as follows:
```json
``{``
  "persons" : [ ``{``
    "name" : "Alice Pauline",
    "phone" : "94351253",
    "email" : "alice@example.com",
    "address" : "123, Jurong West Ave 6, #08-111",
    "tags" : [ "projectX", "projectY" ]
  ``}``, ``{``
    "name" : "Benson Meier",
    "phone" : "98765432",
    "email" : "johnd@example.com",
    "address" : "311, Clementi Ave 2, #02-25",
    "tags" : [ "projectY", "projectX", "projectZ" ]
  ``}``, ``{``
    "name" : "Carl Kurz",
    "phone" : "95352563",
    "email" : "heinz@example.com",
    "address" : "wall street",
    "tags" : [ "projectX" ]
  ``}``, ``{``
    "name" : "Daniel Meier",
    "phone" : "87652533",
    "email" : "cornelia@example.com",
    "address" : "10th street",
    "tags" : [ "projectX", "projectZ" ]
  ``}``, ``{``
    "name" : "Elle Meyer",
    "phone" : "9482224",
    "email" : "werner@example.com",
    "address" : "michegan ave",
    "tags" : [ "projectY", "projectZ" ]
  ``}``, ``{``
    "name" : "Fiona Kunz",
    "phone" : "9482427",
    "email" : "lydia@example.com",
    "address" : "little tokyo",
    "tags" : [ "projectX" ]
  ``}``, ``{``
    "name" : "George Best",
    "phone" : "9482442",
    "email" : "anna@example.com",
    "address" : "4th street",
    "tags" : [ "projectY", "projectX" ]
  ``}`` ]
``}``
```
Now projectX is over. There is no easy way to remove all projectX tags using the app's functions. The user tries changing the json files directly. They want to use find and replace, but do not know what to replace with because there will sometimes be leftover commas. Hence they do the following:
```
find: "projectX"
replace: null
```
Thinking that it worked, they close the data file and do not try opening the app until a few days later.

A few days later, the user tries running the app, but it cannot start/crashes immediately after starting. It is not obvious to them that the issue arose because they changed the data file a few days prior. Referring to the user guide, there is no indication that anything they do can cause the app not to start, nor is there any troubleshooting offered. Changing the data file should only clear the app at worst, not cause the app to be unable to boot. Hence they do not draw the link between their changing of the data file a few days prior, to the current problem of the app not being able to start.

The user is left confused, thinking the app has stopped working.

Hence, I personally believe that it is a valid bug as it can affect real users and the documentation does not align with the behaviour of the app.

However, after reading Prof @damithc 's response to #510, I am not very sure and hope to seek clarification. Thank you!
</panel>

> Problems caused by extreme user behaviors:

if(condition c) then do c;
```

As long as condition a, condition b and condition c are true, all the three will be executed. They're not an if else statement such that only one path can be taken. Also, if condition a is true and condition b is true, the path will be `start -&gt; a -&gt; c` which is different from `start -&gt; b -&gt; c` if condition b and c is true instead. 
</panel>

I haven't had any issues working across Windows and macOS with the same git repository. 

However, I have faced issues when accessing the same repository on Windows WSL (Ubuntu) as described in: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53900839/git-repo-gives-contradictory-info-from-wsl-than-from-windows

TLDR: Difference in the way line endings are interpreted causes conflicts on every line.

Fixed the issue with `git config --global core.autocrlf true`. Alternatively, you can set the git config locally in the `.git` folder for the project.

<panel  header="**7 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/54#issuecomment-1699299735" expanded>

In my opinion, there are two factors to consider:
1. How many people are working together on the repository?
2. Which branch are you pushing to?

For iP, since you're working alone on the project, it's probably quite reasonable to do so. If you don't like having buggy code in `master`, you could always branch out to resolve the code first, then merge back into `master` later on. If you really hate buggy commits in particular, you can do things like `git commit --amend` or `git rebase` to clear buggy commits after you fix them, but note that those will probably require a force push afterward.

For tP, you probably want to avoid pushing to branches that are shared with your group mates, in case they accidentally pull from them. I'm not sure what the tP structure is, but if it's done in forks, then it shouldn't be a big issue anyway. 
</panel>

<panel  header="**5 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/28#issuecomment-1695494062" expanded>

From my experiences, commonly when your program needs to store files locally (I've used this before in my video game projects, about storing player records for the game), here is what I usually do:
```
First, check whether the specific file exists on the disk
  If the file not exists, use one of the two options below:
    --Create the file and initialize the file with initial contents. Then check whether the creation is successful or not. (Exception may happen when space is not enough, doesn't have permission (e.g.: Windows UAC) etc. ) and preceed to the next step
    --Use initial data for this user session, skip the next step and write data later in the write phase (actually I prefer this one)
  If the file exists:
    Preceed to the next step
Second, preceed read/write the file like normal. (the so-called "next step" in the above sentences)
```

So to your question, option 2 is much more reasonable than option 1 since users are not expected to create the data file by themselves in this situation. And what's more, I think you don't need to ask the user whether to save the file, just save it automatically to increase the ease of usage.
</panel>

<panel  header="**3. :fas-info-circle: Clarification of feature freeze rules and bugs that can be fixed**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/405" expanded>



Hi prof, my team and I would like to be very sure we aren't violating any feature freeze rules. Could you help to verify if any of these are violations?

### 1. Parsing and display of year 0000
We have a datetime input and when user inputs year 0000, it is displayed as 0001. 
We have fixed this to display 0000 correctly.

### 2. Unmark accepting multiple m/
We have an unmark command that is supposed to accept just 1 m/ tag. It accepted multiple and we have since restricted it to only 1.

### 3. Theme command ignoring multiple keywords
We have a theme command that is supposed to change the theme by accepting 1 NEWTHEME field. It accepted multiple and took the first word to change. (e.g. theme dark blue was interpreted as theme dark, instead of its intended error)

### 4. Status lost on tutor edit
Editing a tutor caused its associated schedule's statuses to be lost. We have since updated how the command works.

### 5. Calendar schedule being truncated 
We have a `show` command that would display the schedules in a calendar view.
However for schedules with a short duration (under 45 mins etc), it truncate the scheduleâ€™s text due to insufficient width of the schedule box to the extent that none of the words are readable.
Despite this the user can still retrieve the schedule information using the `list-s` schedule command which would display all the added schedules in a list.

We have modified the calendar schedule to not display any text entirely except the index for schedules under 45 mins (this prevents the truncation from occurring in the first place).

### 6. Long fields truncated (schedule n tutors)
We modified the UI view of AB-3 to prevent truncation of long fields with the use of a  horizontal scroll.
However this truncation only occurs for â€œextremeâ€ inputs (names made up of 40 characters of W character etc) and the truncated field can stilll be viewed by the user in full, by resizing the app window manually (for really long names this can take a while).

### 7. Update schedules ordering when day passed 
We have this feature where the product would sort and separate schedules added by the user into two categories:

- Upcoming schedules (including ones that occur on current date)
- Past schedules (those that occured before the current date)

Currently when the day has passed (date changes to the next dayâ€™s date), using of any of the commands does not update the schedules order (move schedules that have occured on that given date to past schedules).
The only way to force this update is to make an edit to a schedule which will update the filtered list of schedules and hence causing a UI update.

We have modified all schedule commands to always sort the list when executed.

### 8. Malformed json causing app to crash
It was stated in the FAQ of feature freeze that the app should support manual edits to the json file. We have updated the product to meet that level of support.

However we did not include the section on support for manual edits to the json file like AB3 did.

### 9. Parsing an Index with a number that is too large returns wrong error message
When parsing a command that uses an index as a parameter, if the index provided is too large (e.g. 99999999999), the parser fails to parse it as an integer and treats it as an invalid parameter and returns an `Invalid command format` error instead of `Invalid index`.

Are we allowed to modify this behaviour to return the correct message by checking if the input is made entirely of numbers before trying to parse as an integer?

Thanks!
</panel>

<panel  header="**4 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/102#issuecomment-1706210621" expanded>

For the first, the coding standard states:
```
Constant names must be all uppercase using underscore to separate words.
```
I believe that constant means it has to be a static variable. Otherwise, for every instance of the class, I can have a different value of that variable. Hence, we use camelCase in this case.
For the second, it states:
```
Plural form should be used on names representing a collection of objects.
```
Hence, I think we should use ```tasks``` as the name instead. However, if there is a case where ```taskList``` is needed for some reason, we notice the following below the standard:
```
Rationale: Enhances readability since the name gives the user an immediate clue of the type of the variable and the operations that can be performed on its elements. One space character after the variable type is enough to obtain clarity.
```
Hence, I think it is okay to leave it in singular form as it hints to people that it is only one list.
</panel>

<panel  header="**5 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/30#issuecomment-1694642727" expanded>

A situation where having a `Storage` class may help is if you plan to store other data files alongside your task list in the future (for example, user settings), and you want to ensure they are stored in a common system- or user-defined location.

Example: Data storage conventions are different across different OSes. For instance, these are possible conventions you might follow (may differ depending on environmental variables or OS versions):

- Windows: `~/AppData/Local/AppName/`
- macOS: `~/Library/Application Support/AppName`
- Other Linux/Unix variants: `~/.config/AppName`

where `~` represents the home directory.

By having a separate `Storage` class, even if it is simply a wrapper on top of the built-in `File`, you can abstract away any operations dealing with the base directory. For instance, when providing a relative path to `Storage` to save a file to, it may auto-create a missing base directory behind the scenes, then auto-prepend the appropriate base directory to the provided relative path before saving.

With this separate wrapper class, any new files used by future features can easily share the same behaviour above.

</panel>

<panel  header="**6 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/30#issuecomment-1695913396" expanded>

I believe the reasons mentioned in 1 and 2 are actually two sides of the same coin. 

Notice `File` and other relevant Java classes themselves are also classes that:

1. require the user to continuously call it, and 
2. requires data passed to it to function. 

and hence technically exhibits the same problem you noted in reason 2. 

With that, since `Storage` is an intermediary of `File` operations (reason 1) it hence makes sense that it exhibits the same "dependency" on each other like `File` (reason 2). 

I feel these design concerns aren't really a big issue if even Java is organised this way.

---

Personally, I think whether you decouple TaskList and Storage is okay either way:

- **IO operations in Storage:** 
  - Since the provided `File` Java APIs also have ways to load and save with different formats via polymorphism, if the purpose of `Storage` is to be a higher-level IO wrapper for internal files, having said class could possibly help in code organisation and future convenience.
  - See also: Java's `BufferedReader`, which is designed to take in and wrap another reader such as `FileReader` for improved performance via buffering.

- **IO operations in TaskList**: 
  - Since it's only used in one place at the moment and we are focusing on iterating on the iP, calling Java File IO APIs within `TaskList` directly has no real downsides yet.


</panel>

<panel  header="**7 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/103#issuecomment-1712837015" expanded>

FYI to all, you may run any script automatically in your browser by simply getting a **userscript** browser extension (available on most browsers, e.g., [Greasemonkey](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/greasemonkey/), [Tampermonkey](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/tampermonkey/dhdgffkkebhmkfjojejmpbldmpobfkfo), [Userscripts](https://apps.apple.com/app/userscripts/id1463298887)), then creating your own userscript. For example, this is sufficient for me:

```js
// ==UserScript==
// @name        CS2103T Menu Autoexpander
// @description Automatically expands all collapsed menus on the CS2103T website.
// @match       *://nus-cs2103-ay2324s1.github.io/website/*
// ==/UserScript==

const collapsibles = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.card-header'));
const uncollapsed = collapsibles.filter(node => ``{``
    const glyph = node.querySelector('.glyphicon');
    if (!glyph) return false;
    return glyph.classList.contains('glyphicon-chevron-right');
``}``);
uncollapsed.forEach(node => node.click());
```

You can do this for any other site as well! :)
</panel>

<panel  header="**6 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/110#issuecomment-1707614410" expanded>

Your `build.gradle` settings should target your `Launcher` class instead of your regular `Duke` class. You can do this by changing the `application` field in `build.gradle` to this:

```java
application ``{``
    mainClass.set("duke.Launcher")
``}``
``` 

Do also make sure there is only one `application` field in the file because I noticed you specified it twice.
</panel>

<panel  header="**7 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/118#issuecomment-1710318989" expanded>

In order to build using Gradle, the project is configured based on your system's version of Java, not the project's. You need to verify that your system is running the correct version of Java too. You can check your system's version of Java using this command:
```shell
java -version
``` 

You should see something like this:
```shell
openjdk version "11.0.20" 2023-07-18 LTS
OpenJDK Runtime Environment Zulu11.66+15-CA (build 11.0.20+8-LTS)
OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM Zulu11.66+15-CA (build 11.0.20+8-LTS, mixed mode)
```

Check the build version of Java, make sure it includes support for JavaFX. You can refer to the course website for more info. https://nus-cs2103-ay2324s1.github.io/website/admin/programmingLanguages.html

</panel>

<panel type="info" header="### 65. NATH..IMAG `@nathanielcalimag` (8 posts) "  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: Which testers are responsible for defending duplicate issues?**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/525" expanded>



Hi prof,

Suppose we have this scenario.

Issue A: Medium, all other issues are duplicates of this
Issue B: High
Issue C: Low
Issue D: Very Low

Suppose the dev team wants to mark issue A as Low, and all testers want to keep their original severity (but agree that their issue is a duplicate). The dev team only responded to issue A, reasoning why it is not medium and it should be low.

<panel  header="**8 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/482#issuecomment-1817428093" expanded>

> > The irritation does not come from the invalidity bug the tester raise, but from how the how the tester is being "Excessive incorrect downgrading/rejecting"
> 
> @yiwen101 "Excessive incorrect downgrading/rejecting" refers to developer response, not bug reports. Testers are not downgrading/rejecting, they are reporting things they think are bugs. If you feel like the tester is _rejecting_ or _downgrading_, you may not be looking at the tester's role in the right way.
> 
> > Firstly, the reported issue is with clear evidence not a bug: ["It's great if you handled such 'invalid data in the JSON file' situations. But I don't think we want to enforce it as a requirement or consider it as a bug, especially because we didn't mention such a requirement earlier."](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2122S2/forum/issues/243)
> 
> To be safe, refrain from referring to previous semester forums. Things may have changed since then, although this statement is still correct.
> 
> > Secondly, the severity is extremely inflated.
> 
> If this is the case, this can only hurt tester's accuracy. It doesn't hurt the receiving team, provided you downgrade the severity to the correct level. So, not really a reason to get upset about.
> 
> > Thirdly, the way the tester inject bugs in the storage is indeed intentional and malicious.
> 
> Not commenting on this specific case but in general it is a good thing when testers do all sorts of nasty things to the product and report what they observe. This is because developers tend to (subconsciously) test their own products 'gently' while testing also need to be 'destructive' at times. Many such observations can be considered and discarded but some may point towards bugs or where the product can be more resilient.
> 
> One of the takeaway from this phase of the PE is to train yourself not to get upset over bug reports. It is not the natural reaction but that's why it needs training. It's like having too many food options at a buffet. Sure, it takes extra time to consider all options, but in the end, you just eat what you want and ignore the rest. Likewise, just reject the bug reports that are not really bugs. In our context (not in a real project), you can also be thankful that the tester wasted time reporting non-bugs, thus possibly reducing the real bug count, and your penalty.
> 
> > No reasonable advanced user with reasonable skill and intention of modifying the data file directly will put null(unquoted) randomly in the data file when it clearly contradicts to the format and pattern the data is stored.
> 
> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1673303/283979868-886ae13a-5da4-4c85-aab8-7fb22d29a554.png)
> 
> Considering the above, you may be able to reject such bugs, in which case only the tester lose accuracy, no harm to your team. In a real project scenario (not in our tP/PE context), it is best not to assume the user will not do this and that. For example, it is also possible that an amateur will think of themselves as an 'advanced user', try to modify the data file, and mess it up. While it is fine not to cater for everything user might do, it is also good to be able to survive or gracefully fail no matter what the user throws at your application.

I see. Thank you for your prompt and kind response.

"One of the takeaway from this phase of the PE is... It is not the natural reaction but that's why it needs training... the rest."

I appreciate how enlightening the response is. Thank you again for not only correcting my wrong cognition about testing, but also guide me to adopt growth mindset and benefit from the event.


</panel>

</panel>

<panel  header="**2. :fas-info-circle: Clarification on cannot be fixed independently**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/516" expanded>

Hi prof, according to the course website,

![image](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/assets/87511888/05397a4b-7d76-47c7-84bc-f46c3a2b1859)

two bug reports can be flagged duplicates if they are not obvious duplicates but "cannot be fixed independently". I want to clarify if it qualifies if the solutions to the two bugs have a high degree of overlap. In particular, does it qualify if:

1. The problems are with `ACommand` and `BCommand`. The problem can be resolved by declaring a new method `example` in `Model`, but the two command classes `ACommand` and `BCommand` still needs to make independent calls to the method `Model::example`.
2. Both problems are associated with the generic method `X::&lt;T>method`, which depends on a generic class `G&lt;T>`. Here `X` is a class declared in the programme, and `G&lt;T>` is a generic class imported from a java default package. `T` binds to class `A` in problem 1 and `T` binds to class `B` in problem 2. Both problems can be resolved by declaring `T` in the generic method `X::&lt;T>method` to extend a new interface `I` that has method `example`, i.e. `&lt;T extends I>`, so that `I::example` can be called in the method. The code now will only compile if classes `A` and `B` implements `I`, however, the implementation of `I::example` must be correct in `A` and `B` in order for each problem to be resolved.

Also, can I ask if I can use the team's code base to prove that the two problems cannot be fixed independently?
</panel>

<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: Clarification regarding whether the following bug can be fixed**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/418" expanded>

Hi Prof, our team discovered the following bug in our app:

1) Create a leave application (Leave Application 1) tagged to a person e.g. Person A. The leave application will indicate that it belongs to Person A.
2) Close the app.
3) Reopen the app.
4) Rename Person A to Person B.

This causes a bug as Leave Application 1 will not update to indicate it now belongs to Person B. This is an issue for the following reasons:
1) When trying to find leave applications belonging to Person B, Leave Application 1 will not appear even though it is supposed to belong to Person B.
2) If we close the app and reopen it again, Leave Application 1 will disappear since leaves are loaded only if they can be associated with an existing person in the address book. Since Leave Application 1 is associated with Person A and Person A no longer exists in the address book, Leave Application 1 will not be loaded and thus be lost.

We noted that the leave application does update if it was created in the current session i.e. the following sequence works:
1) Create Leave Application 2 tagged to Person A.
2) Rename Person A as Person B.

Leave Application 2 will update to indicate it belongs to Person B. As such, could we argue that there is a reasonable expectation that the person's name in the leave application should change when the person's name changes and thus be allowed to fix it? Our team has identified a fix that only requires changing one line of code, thus there is minimal code change. Thank you!
</panel>

<panel  header="**2. :fas-info-circle: Clarification regarding acceptable bug fixes**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/410" expanded>

Hi Prof, while reviewing our existing commits for v1.4, our team realised there were some bug fixes that we were unsure whether they might violate the feature freeze, and thus, we would like to seek clarification to decide whether we may have to revert some of our changes. They are as follows:

1) For some of the commands, we noted in the UG that missing fields and invalid inputs would throw specific error messages, but currently they all return the generic "Invalid command format" error message (e.g. [106](https://github.com/AY2324S1-CS2103T-W11-1/tp/issues/106) , [113](https://github.com/AY2324S1-CS2103T-W11-1/tp/issues/113) ). Our team feels that since the app is not behaving according to what the UG describes, it might be considered a bug, but we would like to seek your opinion nonetheless.

2) There is a bug where adding a tag to the person would cause the employee list to reset and display all employees rather than showing the same filtered view as before (see [120](https://github.com/AY2324S1-CS2103T-W11-1/tp/issues/120) ). Our team feels that the reasonable behaviour would be not to reset the list when a tag is added and has identified a fix involving deleting one line of code, but are unsure if it can be considered a bug.

3) Within the usage message for one of our commands (`add-leave`), it incorrectly lists the Description field as a required field rather than an optional field, which is the behaviour of the app as well as what the UG describes (see [124](https://github.com/AY2324S1-CS2103T-W11-1/tp/issues/124) ). Are we allowed to change the usage message to reflect the correct format?

4) Currently, the name field only accepts alphanumeric characters and spaces. However, this would mean that valid names e.g. Daniel Day-Lewis would be rejected, as it involves a hyphen. As such, can we modify the validation to accept these names?

5) Our app currently uses a CSV parser with semicolons as the delimiter. However, we are considering switching to comma delimiters instead, as highlighted by (135)[https://github.com/AY2324S1-CS2103T-W11-1/tp/issues/135] . From the bug report created, it is arguably not a bug on the part of our app, as the imported CSV file does not use semicolons as delimiters due to Excel's overwriting of the file. As such, our team is unsure whether we can fix this issue.

6) For the issue of text wrapping/truncation, may we clarify if typical inputs for a particular field would likely result in text overflow, that we are allowed to fix it? For instance, we provide a field for adding descriptions to leaves in our app. Our team estimated that since a typical leave description could be well over 100-200 characters, it would likely encounter text overflow. In this context, may we be allowed to fix it?

7) May we clarify if refactoring exception handling is allowed for v1.4? Currently, we have a PR that refactors exception handling, such that they are handled in a lower abstraction layer. This change will not cause any regressions, but may reduce the likelihood of uncaught exceptions being thrown during PE due to better exception handling. As such, our team would like to know if we are allowed to merge these changes into our repo.

Thank you!
</panel>

<panel  header="**3. :fas-info-circle: Feature Freeze: Dealing with undefined or ambiguous behavior**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/371" expanded>

Suppose that we have a delete command that have 2 modes: deleting Type-A and deleting Type-B

e.g. `delete INDEX` to delete Type-A,  and  `delete --B INDEX` to delete Type-B 

However, it turns out that both can be specified together: `delete INDEX --B INDEX`, and the command will delete Type-B and ignore Type-A

This behavior is not documented in the UG.

Would changing this behavior to give the user a command syntax error violate the feature freeze?
</panel>

<panel  header="**4 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/371#issuecomment-1802161696" expanded>

`delete INDEX INDEX` will give the user an invalid ID error message (this is expected as my team's current delete command also accepts ID as a parameter for deletion instead of index, and the delete command can only delete 1 at a time unless it is specified to be recursive)

However, `delete INDEX_1 --B INDEX_2 ` will give the message that the item of Type-B is deleted, and if INDEX_2 is invalid, it will give the error message related to deleting Type-B. This also does not check if INDEX_1 is a valid index.
</panel>

Question stated that "the Goo interface doesn't have any default method implementation", for Bar to be a concrete class it has to provide an implementation for store().

On the other hand the process() method is not italicized and there is no ``{``abstract``}`` keyword. Hence it is not an abstract method and has a default implementation in the abstract class Foo.

I think Java allows definition of abstract classes without any abstract methods https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4811678/defining-an-abstract-class-without-any-abstract-methods
</panel>

<panel  header="**7 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/556#issuecomment-1832953661" expanded>

Another hypothetical scenario I can think of: abstract class ProgressWatcher could have provided an implementation of the +update(int) method, while the UiWidget just extends the abstract class ProgressWatcher without overriding the +update(int) method in ProgressWatcher.

Now the +update(int) method will be written in ProgressWatcher instead. Hence I think it is necessary to show where there has been an implementation of the +update(int) method.

Extending from my scenario, if the UiWidget overrides the +update(int) method in ProgressWatcher. I think +update(int) method will have to be written in both ProgressWatcher and UiWidget.
</panel>

Hi, our team is currently facing challenges in determining whether the enhancements listed below align with the v1.4 constraints. Could you please identify which enhancements comply with the constraints and which ones may not? Thank you!

1. Current constraints allow appointments with dates before the current date to be added, which does not make sense in the context of an appointment tracker. However, we did not introduce this constraint in our current iteration, is this still considered a bug and as such we can increase the constraints to only accept the dates after the current date.

2. NRIC parameter accepts invalid NRICs such as ones starting with A, which does not accurately reflect real world context. However, this does not affect the overall functionality of the app as valid NRICs are still being accepted, can we increase the constraint to only accept valid NRICs?

3. As our app is an addressbook for patient management, some patients might not have an NRIC, eg foreigners. Is it considered a bug to have the NRIC parameter be a compulsory field when adding a patient?

4. Name parameter currently does not allow dots and dashes. As some peopleâ€™s names may contain dots or dashes, could we edit the parameter to allow them?

5. When an invalid patient index is entered, our current output is â€œInvalid outputâ€. A suggestion during PE-D was to make it more verbose. As such, can we edit it to reflect the maximum allowable index that is valid?

6. When a record with duplicate conditions or medications is added, our app allowed the duplicates and ui shows multiple entries of the same conditions and medication. Suggestion was made during PE-D to filter out duplicate entries. Would implementing such suggestion be violation of feature freeze?

7. Is it considered a violation to change the "wraptext" attribute to true for the name label on the current name card, considering that the existing name might be quite lengthy, and enabling wrapping would display the overflow in ellipsis?

<panel type="info" header="### 95. LOW ..HONG `@junhonglow` (5 posts) <span class=text-warning>:octicon-eye:</span>"  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: JavaDoc conventions, AB3 or Java Coding Standard?**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/289" expanded>

Some parts of AB3 currently uses the following convention for writing Javadoc.
```java
/**
 * Replaces the given person ``{``@code target``}`` in the list with ``{``@code editedPerson``}``.
 * ``{``@code target``}`` must exist in the address book.
 * The person identity of ``{``@code editedPerson``}`` must not be the same as another existing person in the address book.
 */
public void setPerson(Person target, Person editedPerson) ``{``
    requireNonNull(editedPerson);

    persons.setPerson(target, editedPerson);
``}``
```
Given the same piece of code, if I choose to follow the Java Coding Standard, I might expect something of the following instead, with the most notable difference being the uses of @ tags.
```java
/**
 * Replaces the given person in the list with the edited person.
 * The given person must exist in the address book.
 * The identity of the edited person must not be the same as an existing person in the address book.
 * 
 * @param target Person to be replaced in the address book.
 * @param editedPerson The person to replace the target with.
 */
```
Should Javadoc be written strictly following the Java Coding Standard? 
If so, I assume that we would not need to modify any previously written Javadoc in AB3?
</panel>

You can try running the following commands to rename the tag and update your remote repository

###  Step 1: Rename the tag
```
git tag [new_tag_name] [old_tag_name]
```

### Step 2: Delete the old tag
```
git tag -d [old_tag_name]
```

### Step 3: Update Remote Repository
```
git push origin [new_tag_name] :[old_tag_name]
```

</panel>
