<panel  header="**4 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/146#issuecomment-1720759103" expanded>

The creation of 2 jar files is because you specified the `dependsOn("distZip", "distTar")` in the configuration. So when shadowJar is run, it'll execute these tasks resulting in the creation of the additional ip.jar file.

If you dont need the distribution archives, you can remove the `dependsOn("distZip", "distTar")` line from the configuration and it should only generate the `duke.jar` file.

<panel  header="**5 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/253#issuecomment-1760904488" expanded>

Thank you so much prof, we have just figured out the issue and all OS is now passing the CI Check.

The problem was with the overloaded JsonAdaptedPerson Constructor that we have created. We overloaded the constructor because we added new fields to Person Constructor but have yet to make corresponding changes in Test folder. As a result of this overloaded constructor, Windows OS occasionally fails and Macos always fails potentially due to how they interact with the JsonCreator and JsonProperty.

Before
```
@JsonCreator
public JsonAdaptedPerson(@JsonProperty("name") String name, @JsonProperty("nric") String nric,
                             @JsonProperty("phone") String phone, @JsonProperty("email") String email,
                             @JsonProperty("address") String address, @JsonProperty("appointment") String appointment,
                             @JsonProperty("medicalHistories") List<JsonAdaptedMedicalHistory> medicalHistories,
            @JsonProperty("tags") List<JsonAdaptedTag> tags) 
            
public JsonAdaptedPerson(@JsonProperty("name") String name,
                             @JsonProperty("phone") String phone, @JsonProperty("email") String email,
                             @JsonProperty("address") String address,
                             @JsonProperty("tags") List<JsonAdaptedTag> tags) ``{``
```

After
```
@JsonCreator
public JsonAdaptedPerson(@JsonProperty("name") String name, @JsonProperty("nric") String nric,
                             @JsonProperty("phone") String phone, @JsonProperty("email") String email,
                             @JsonProperty("address") String address, @JsonProperty("appointment") String appointment,
                             @JsonProperty("medicalHistories") List<JsonAdaptedMedicalHistory> medicalHistories,
            @JsonProperty("tags") List<JsonAdaptedTag> tags) 
            
public JsonAdaptedPerson(String name,
                             String phone, String email,
                             String address,
                             List<JsonAdaptedTag> tags) ``{``
```

Thank you all for the debugging suggestions. Credits @WZWren  
</panel>

</panel>

<panel type="info" header="### 109. CHU ..RONG `@wr1159` (5 posts) "  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: Feature Flaw or Functionality Bug?**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/370" expanded>



## Context
My team's tp has a feature to enrol a member to an event and there are several operations that can be performed. First of all, we can go into this 'view' mode where user views the members enrolled to the specific event and vice versa. In this view mode, we can then run several operations to edit the data regarding the enrolment.

| Original View | Event View Mode |
|--------|--------|
| <img width="1483" alt="image" src="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/assets/56021409/98a32e7a-5ff4-4a07-880b-14c3217f1679"> | <img width="1485" alt="image" src="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/assets/56021409/49f532ea-a4ed-476b-8bf8-5079062629b8"> |


## Questions

1. When editing the enrolment information, the newly edited information does not show up on the UI and can only be seen when running the view command again. This was not our intended behaviour as the UI should refresh immediately, however, the team is conflicted - is this a functionality bug or a feature flaw?

2. Similarly, users can unenrol the member from the event which should result in the UI updating, removing the member from the list, however the user remains in the view. Similarly to above, the user can run the view command again to view the refreshed UI. Is this a functionality bug or feature flaw since users might be mistaken that the command did not work.

3. In the event view mode, when users edit the attributes of the member / event (not the enrolment), the UI bounces back to the main view. This differs from the intended behaviour where user should remain on their current view. The team was leaning towards it being a feature flaw but we would like to confirm whether it is indeed a feature flaw.

Edit: Added a third question.
</panel>

I understand that when we create unit tests for a particular method, we should isolate the method from its dependencies. However, how about the following case:

```
class Foo ``{``
    public Bar fooMethod() ``{``
        return new Bar();
    ``}``
``}``
```

Here, it seems that it is impossible to isolate `fooMethod` from the `Bar` class as it is supposed to return it. In such cases, can we assume that it is okay not to isolate the two? <panel  header="**2. :fas-info-circle: Is Decoupling TaskList and Storage Necessary?**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/30" expanded>

I personally think creating two different classes for list of tasks and storage is not necessary. The reason for which is as follows:
1. One cannot exist without the other. TaskList will be stored using Storage and Storage serves only as an intermediary between file storage and TaskList; a task already achieved by `IO::File` class.
2. One cannot operate without the other. TaskList's method is continuously calling Storage's method and Storage's method needs TaskList's data passed to it to operate.
3. Neither is used by other feature. At least as of right now, neither TaskList nor Storage is used by any other class and it is hard for me to see in which scenario this won't be the case.

As such, we've created a scenario where we try to separate two tightly coupled systems to achieve what could be done better (in terms of performance, ease of development, and design) by simply implementing additional methods. In case I missed anything, I would love to hear more reason as to why creating the Storage class is actually necessary. Thank you
</panel>

<panel  header="**3 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/30#issuecomment-1694684827" expanded>

Hm I see what you mean, thanks for the response. Elaborating on your case, however, unless we want to impose an implicit rule on how the data is formatted for every kind of data (which we don't), we need to basically create an interface with "save" and "load" method that will be implemented differently for each data format. Then we proceed by creating a `TaskStorage implements Storage` class which will be tightly coupled with our `TaskList` class.

While I understand that this is preferable in projects that have multiple features with other data files, I think creating a `Storage` as a class (and not interface) for our project is rather useless; it doesn't solve the problem you mentioned and at least the first two issues I brought up with this design still persist.
</panel>

What I did is:
1. Go to Project Structure in IntelliJ, then download and change the SDK version to 11.

3. Check java version of your local computer by running `java -version` in terminal to make sure it has been changed to 11.
4. Run the jar file again.

<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡ Auto fix imports on save**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/291" expanded>

I used to order the imports manually, which is very time-consuming manually. So here's the configuration for you to auto order your inputs every time you save on Intellij!

1. Go to `Settings/System Preference` > `Tools` > `Actions on Save` and tick `Optimise Imports`
2. Go to `Code Style` > `Java` >  `Imports` > `General` and tick `Use fully qualified class names`. This makes sure all uses of `*` are expanded
3. Under the same `Imports` tab, go to `Import Layout` and rearrange the imports as such:
a) import static all other imports
b) <blank line>
c) import javax.*
d) import java.*
e) <blank line>
f) import all other imports
4. Click `Apply`
<img width="729" alt="image" src="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/assets/111076731/8cc08184-f724-4439-962d-4da7d9eff057">

That's it!
</panel>

 ``}``

The issue arises because the FileWriter essentially truncates the file when it is opened for writing. This means that the contents of the file are erased, and the file becomes empty. As a result, when you subsequently call setup.hasNext() right after creating the FileWriter, it returns false because there are no more tokens to read â€“ the file is empty.

In the [Conventional Commits format](https://www.conventionalcommits.org/), the subject line would be prefixed with a type, such as `feat` or `fix`, which is in lowercase. This conflicts with the [course's Git conventions](https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/git.html), which require the first letter of the subject line to be capitalized.

Are we allowed to use the Conventional Commits format? 

Example: `feat: Add save/load functionality`

Or should we follow the course's Git conventions strictly, and use the following instead?

Example: `Feat: Add save/load functionality`

Or are we not allowed to use Conventional Commits at all?

Example: `Add save/load functionality`

Thank you.

Update: Managed to fix the issue. Thank you @dinde2004 for your help.

What I did was:
1. Redownload SDK version 11
2. Overwrite value of environment variable JAVA_HOME to my java version 11 path following step 2 (here)[https://www.happycoders.eu/java/how-to-switch-multiple-java-versions-windows/]
3. Go to project structure and change SDK to 11 and language level to 11
4. Delete .idea and .gradle file
5. Click on Build > Rebuild Project
6. Recreate JAR file using [tutorial link](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/jar.html)

Other issues I encountered during my rebuilding of project:
IntelliJ cannot open Terminal Window
1. Go to IntelliJ and click on Settings > Tools > Terminal
2. Change shell path to: `C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe`
3. Apply changes and restart IntelliJ

</panel>

</panel>

In addition, if you want to tag a specific commit without a tag that is not the most recent one (and hence renaming is impossible), you can do the following
### Step 1: Find the commit
Run `git log` and use the vim motion keys `j` and `k` to find the specific commit. Copy the commit's hash (the long string of hexadecimal after the word `commit`) and press `q` to quit.
### Step 2: Add the tag
```
git tag [tag_name] [commit_hash]
```
Confusingly, this has the same syntax as renaming the tag as mentioned above.
### Step 3: Update the remote repository
```
git push origin --tags
```

<panel type="info" header="### 181. WONG..RAND `@peasantbird` (2 posts) "  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: Clarification of feature freeze rules and bugs that can be fixed**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/438" expanded>

Hi prof, my team and I would like to be very sure we aren't violating any feature freeze rules. Could you help to verify if any of these are violations?

### 1. UG does not include default sort
Our sort command for v1.3 sorts the list of persons based on a prefix and sort order (included in the UG), but also sorts by the default input order when no prefix and sort order is given (not included in the UG). Is adding this already implemented feature into the UG considered a feature freeze violation or a bug? Should we remove this feature or is adding it to the UG okay?

### 2. Sort command takes in invalid parameters and does the default sort
Our sort command takes in invalid parameters like `sort qwerty` and invalid prefixes and sort orders like `sort qwerty/asdf` and does the default sort since there are no valid prefixes and sort orders. This behavior was not recorded down in our UG. Will implementing a check for invalid parameters and invalid prefixes and sort orders and showing an error message to the user be a feature freeze violation or a bug fix? Would recording this behavior into our UG be okay?

### 3. Sort command takes in extra valid prefixes
Our sort commands takes in extra valid prefixes like `sort prio/d n/d` and only does the first sort, i.e. `sort prio/d`. This behavior was not recorded down in our UG. Will implementing a check for extra prefixes and showing an error message to the user be a feature freeze violation or a bug fix? Would recording this behavior into our UG be okay?

### 4. Changes to sort command error message for invalid sort order
When the sort order is wrong, the sort command throws a general error message on how to use the sort command. Will changing the error message to tell the user that the sort order is wrong be a feature freeze violation or a bug fix?

> @LuoZYi You seem to be using [Git sub modules](https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Tools-Submodules) in your repo. Specifically, `src/main/java` folder is configured as a sub module (i.e., it resides as a separate repo elsewhere). You need to remove that and replace the folder with the regular files instead. Otherwise not only CI will fail but also our scripts will have no Java code to grade your iP.

Thank you so much prof! I have now successfully set up the page with your suggestion! I realized that previously I set up the project at the wrong path, i.e. at` src/main/java`, and I think all my branches are also at that folder. Thank you so much prof for your help!

    implementation 'org.openjfx:javafx-graphics:17.0.7:win'
``}``

test ``{``

        events "passed", "skipped", "failed"

<panel type="info" header="### 224. JOEL..MENG `@joel-foo` (1 posts) "  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/86#issuecomment-1704054583" expanded>

Yes, because the Scene builder is v20, once you update the FXML file using Scene builder, the FXML file will use javafx v20. 

I think there are two ways to solve this
1. Use scene builder v17 instead

or

2.  In you fxml files, after you are done with editing using scene builder, manually update the value of the `xmlns` attribute of the 1st XML opening tag.

For example, changing

`&lt;fx:root alignment="TOP_RIGHT" maxHeight="1.7976931348623157E308" prefWidth="400.0" type="javafx.scene.layout.HBox" xmlns="http://javafx.com/javafx/20" xmlns:fx="http://javafx.com/fxml/1">`

to 

`&lt;fx:root alignment="TOP_RIGHT" maxHeight="1.7976931348623157E308" prefWidth="400.0" type="javafx.scene.layout.HBox" xmlns="http://javafx.com/javafx/17" xmlns:fx="http://javafx.com/fxml/1">`

in the relevant xml files will make the warning go away. 

Note that if use method 2, you will have to update that everytime you change any files using Scene builder.
</panel>

</panel>

<panel  header="**1 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/73#issuecomment-1703890557" expanded>

## Verify your SSH keys

Did you create an SSH keypair on your system? If you didn't, perhaps in week 2 you used the HTTPS URL i.e. https://... instead of the SSH URL to fetch from GitHub, and perhaps you might want to revert to that i.e. `git remote set-url origin &lt;http url>`.

Otherwise, can you check that your SSH keys exist and haven't changed. If you aren't sure where it is and didn't do any special configuration other than googling "how to create SSH key", you can usually find your key-pair at `~/.ssh`.

Run `cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub` and check that there's some output that starts with `ssh-rsa`. **Do not `cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa` (notice there's no .pub file extension here) and never send the output from that anywhere.**

## Check your SSH keys on GitHub

Go to the SSH keys configuration page at https://github.com/settings/keys and check that there's at least one SSH key listed there. Ensure that your SSH key output from before (the `id_rsa.pub` file) matches the SSH key listed there. If it doesn't, create a new entry and add the output from before there.

**Again, do not do not do not copy and paste the output from `id_rsa`, copy the output from `id_rsa.pub`.**
</panel>

</panel>

<panel type="info" header="### 248. JEFF.. JIE `@jeffrey-jian` (1 posts) "  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡ Resolve Error: Unable to construct Application instance: class duke.Duke**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/issues/111" expanded>

Following the [JavaFx tutorial guide](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/javaFxPart1.html), after copying the `start` method into your Duke.java file, 

```java
@Override
    public void start(Stage stage) ``{``
        Label helloWorld = new Label("Hello World!"); // Creating a new Label control
        Scene scene = new Scene(helloWorld); // Setting the scene to be our Label

        stage.setScene(scene); // Setting the stage to show our screen
        stage.show(); // Render the stage.
    ``}``
```

you may encounter the following error when you attempt to run the application:

<img width="1036" alt="Screenshot 2023-09-06 at 3 21 31 PM" src="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S1/forum/assets/74343245/a9766d00-84a6-4fc8-b444-a26423bbe5af">

### Fix 

You will have to create an overloaded constructor that takes in **no** parameters.

>Calling Application.launch(...) causes an instance of your Application subclass to be created, the FX Application toolkit to be started, and start() to be invoked on the created instance.
>
>--<cite>source: [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37634688/cant-run-my-javafx-program-caused-by-java-lang-runtimeexception)


The Application instance is created by calling the no-argument constructor, so the Application subclass, `Duke`, needs to define one:

E.g. if your `Duke` constructor looks something like this:

```java
public Duke(String filePath) ``{``
    // code here
``}``
```

add an overloaded public constructor that takes in no parameters:

```java
public Duke() ``{``
    this(DEFAULT_FILE_PATH);
``}``
```

Hope this helps!


</panel>

</panel>
